item.title: Step 1: Examine Source Data
item.description:
Examine the Source Data

Overview

Before mapping any data, you need to understand what you’re working with. In this step, you’ll examine the customer CSV file to understand its structure, fields, and data quality.

Locate the Source Data

The customer data is located at:

/home/ubuntu/workshop/workspace/customers/customers.csv

Examine the Data

  • Opening the file in the IDE
  • Reviewing the header row
  • Looking at sample records
  • Identifying data types
  • Noting any quality issues

item.title: Step 2: Create Schema

Provide or Create the Schema

Overview

Now that you’ve examined the data, you need to document its schema. You can use the Senzing schema generator tool to automatically analyze the CSV and create a schema document.

Using the Schema Generator

TODO: Instructions for running the schema generator will go here.

  • Running sz_schema_generator.py on the customers CSV

item.title: Step 3: Map the Schema
item.description:
Use the Senzing Mapping Assistant

Overview

Now you’ll use the Senzing Mapping Assistant prompt with Amazon Q to guide you through the mapping process. This AI-assisted workflow takes you through 5 stages to create a complete mapper.

The 5-Stage Workflow

The Mapping Assistant guides you through:

  1. INIT - Load reference files and verify tools
  2. INVENTORY - Analyze source data schema
  3. PLANNING - Determine data source and entity types
  4. MAPPING - Map fields to Senzing features
  5. OUTPUTS - Generate mapper script and documentation

Start the Mapping Assistant

Prompt to use:

item.title: Step 5: Load Data

Load the Data in Senzing

Overview

Now that your mapping is validated, load the customer data into Senzing for entity resolution. Senzing will analyze the records and identify which ones represent the same real-world entities.

item.title: Step 8: Review Examples
item.description:
Review with MCP Server

Overview

Use the Senzing MCP Server through Amazon Q to explore entity resolution results interactively. Ask “how” and “why” questions to understand resolution decisions.

Using the MCP Server

Now that data is loaded, you can use conversational AI to query and understand the results.

Example Question 1: Get an Entity

Ask Amazon Q:

Get entity 1
